segment.source: How to Branch a Package
segment.target: How to Branch a Package

segment.source: How to Branch a Package
segment.target: How to Branch a Package

segment.source: How to Branch a Package
segment.target: How to Branch a Package

segment.source: Use this procedure to modify an existing sequenced application package so you can run it side-by-side with the original sequenced application package.
segment.target: Use this procedure to modify an existing sequenced application package so you can run it side-by-side with the original sequenced application package.

segment.source: This process is called branching.
segment.target: This process is called branching.

segment.source: When you branch a virtual application package you are able to run two versions of the same package.
segment.target: When you branch a virtual application package you are able to run two versions of the same package.

segment.source: For example, you can apply a service pack to an existing package, and run it side-by-side with the original sequenced virtual application package.
segment.target: For example, you can apply a service pack to an existing package, and run it side-by-side with the original sequenced virtual application package.

segment.source: Use the following procedure to branch a sequenced virtual application package.
segment.target: Use the following procedure to branch a sequenced virtual application package.

segment.source: To branch a sequenced virtual application package
segment.target: To branch a sequenced virtual application package

segment.source: Open the Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) Sequencer.
segment.target: Open the Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) Sequencer.

segment.source: To specify the destination directory that contains the package (.sprj) you want to branch select File, Open.
segment.target: To specify the destination directory that contains the package (.sprj) you want to branch select File, Open.

segment.source: Navigate to the directory that contains the sequenced application you plan to branch and click Open.
segment.target: Navigate to the directory that contains the sequenced application you plan to branch and click Open.

segment.source: To save a copy of the package, in the App-V Sequencer, select File, Save As.
segment.target: To save a copy of the package, in the App-V Sequencer, select File, Save As.

segment.source: Specify a new, unique name, and specify a new unique package root directory for the copy of the package.
segment.target: Specify a new, unique name, and specify a new unique package root directory for the copy of the package.

segment.source: Click Save.
segment.target: Click Save.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You must specify a new package name or you will overwrite the existing version of the package.
segment.target: You must specify a new package name or you will overwrite the existing version of the package.

segment.source: The sequencer will automatically generate new GUID files for the new package.
segment.target: The sequencer will automatically generate new GUID files for the new package.

segment.source: The version number associated with the package will also be automatically appended to the OSD file name.
segment.target: The version number associated with the package will also be automatically appended to the OSD file name.

segment.source: After you save the new version you can apply the required configuration changes and save the associated ICO, OSD, SFT, and SPRJ files to correct location on the Application Virtualization (App-V) server.
segment.target: After you save the new version you can apply the required configuration changes and save the associated ICO, OSD, SFT, and SPRJ files to correct location on the Application Virtualization (App-V) server.
